section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Dori Kleber and illustrated by G. Brian Karas
section-block.rac_book_summary: Joey loves things that fold. He is very excited when he learns about origami, the Japanese art of folding paper. However, it is more difficult than he expected! Practice finding and talking about shapes as Joey practices to become an origami master.

section-block.rac_body-text: Use Pattern Blocks to help children identify squares and triangles. Flip and turn the shapes in all directions to show that orientation does not change the shape.
Sing “Pat-a-Cake” together and have children make the motions of rolling, patting, and marking the dough. Explain that baking can be a kind of art, just like folding paper.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we will read More-igami by Dori Kleber and illustrated by G. Brian Karas.
You know that Lala loves books, especially stories with lots of shapes!
Here is a question to think about. We will talk about it after we read: What is one thing Joey folded in the story?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Geometry: As you read, have children watch for and identify familiar shapes in the illustrations.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The title of this book is More-igami. Let’s break it down to think about what it means. I see the word more! And -igami makes me think of origami. I think the title is a fun way to say “More Origami!”
Joey sleeps in a foldaway bed. What do you think foldaway means? Let’s look at the smaller words inside the big word: fold and away. It’s a bed that you can fold to put away!
What shapes do you see in this picture?
Why do Joey’s eyes pop and his jaw drop? How does Joey feel? Why does Joey ask Mrs. Takimoto to teach him? (MB)
Joey practiced by folding everything he could find! What did Joey fold?
Why was Joey sad? Does eating your favorite food ever make you feel better?
I see a lot of shapes on these pages. What shapes do you see?
Why do the girl’s eyes pop and her jaw drop? What does she like to do with paper?
What shapes do you see in this picture?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What is one thing Joey folded in the story?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
Write and read aloud short sentences about creating different kinds of art as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Joey fold in the restaurant?
If you were learning origami, what would you fold?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Guided play with Pattern Blocks can help children attain geometric understanding and introduce them to the vocabulary of geometry. Give children opportunities to sort and name shapes, and create new shapes by combining other shapes.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Initiative
section-block.rac_body-text: A lot of the time, adults tell you what to do. But sometimes you can decide what to do. When you work on your own, you can choose which paints to use, what games to play, and what book you want to read. Figuring out what you like to do and deciding how to do it is a huge part of learning! Ask children when they have tried to learn or do something new on their own.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread More-igami by Dori Kleber and illustrated by G. Brian Karas. We will talk about how Joey took initiative and solved problems on his own.
Clifford loves reading stories and noticing how characters take initiative. He likes to read about children who make decisions for themselves.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose several children to answer questions.
Focus on Geometry: As you read, point out shapes in the pictures.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Joey collect road maps and play the accordion? It seems like Joey takes the initiative to collect things that fold. (MB)
Joey wants to take the initiative to learn origami. Mrs. Takimoto says it will take practice for Joey to become an origami master. (MB)
What did Joey do to show he was taking the initiative to learn origami? What did he do to practice? (MB)
Joey has a problem! He can’t practice at home. How will Joey solve his problem? (MB)
Mr. López calls Joey amigo. That means friend in Spanish. Sometimes, our friends speak different languages than we do. Do you know how to say hello in another language?
Let’s talk about the shapes we see on this page. I see triangles on the sides of the pyramids.
Joey made a crane! Why was it important for Joey to keep practicing?

section.rac_body-text: Give each child a small pile of Pattern Blocks. Ask children to create something with the shapes. What they make and how they make it is entirely up to them! As children finish creating, ask volunteers to describe what they made and why.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell about making art using shapes.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: A classroom environment that allows for failure and occasional child choice is one that will help children develop initiative and problem-solving skills. Creative play stations and opportunities to choose among activities are essential for developing this skill, which is critical for success in school and in life. (physicianscenter.org/parents)

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children a square Pattern Block and discuss its features. Then, hold up a Connecting Cube. Explain that a cube has squares for each of its six sides. it is not flat.
Ask children to fold paper squares to make a shape. Have each child hold up his or her creation and describe it. Is your paper still flat? What shape did you make?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book More-igami by Dori Kleber and illustrated by G. Brian Karas.
Lala loves reading books that tell stories, like this one!
Joey didn’t learn to make origami in only one day! It took him time and practice. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How did Joey learn to make origami?

section.rac_body-text: As you read, pause to discuss two- and three-dimensional shapes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Mrs. Takimoto is holding a piece of paper! What shape is it? Is it a flat shape? How can you tell?
Joey practiced on a lot of different kinds of paper! What kinds of paper did he practice folding with?
Joey can’t practice at home, so he asks Mr. López for help! Why is it important to ask others for help if we have a problem we can’t solve on our own? (MB)
I see a lot of napkins folded to look like pyramids in this picture! I can also see that the sides of the pyramids are made out of triangles. Which shape is flat, and which is not?
What other napkin shapes did Joey learn to fold? What did he do when the napkins toppled and flopped?
Did you listen and remember as we read today? How did Joey learn to make origami?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk.Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Joey practiced folding so many different kinds of paper.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about flat and three-dimensional shapes.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Joey do so he could learn to make origami?
What kind of art would you like to practice making?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The English words triangle (triángulo), circle (circulo), and pyramid (pirámide) have close Spanish equivalents, but square (cuadrado) does not. Children will be expected to know some basic shapes by kindergarten, so give all children ample time to manipulate and name Pattern Blocks or other shape manipulatives.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk to children about ways to make art beyond painting and drawing. If possible, show photos of sculptures and pottery.
Have children spread out. Play music and invite children to dance. When you stop the music and say “statue,” all children freeze in place. Dance again when the music starts.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read A Horse, of Course. It is an informational poster about making art.
More-igami and A Horse, of Course are both about making art. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
How can we express ourselves through making art?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Classification: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and sort the artwork into groups.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The title is A Horse, of Course. Let’s look at the words one by one to figure out what it means.
A horse is an animal. Of course is a phrase that means “clearly.” I can clearly see that each artwork on this page shows a horse!
Cave people didn’t have paper. But they wanted to draw! How did they solve their problem?
An artist sculpted these horses. Do you think you could sculpt a horse like this?
What shapes do you see in this picture?
This horse is made of paper. How is this paper art different from origami?
What shapes did the artist mold to create this horse?
Let’s sort the artwork on this chart! How many of these horses are flat? How many are not flat? How can you tell?

section.rac_body-text: Have children create art using their bodies. Have each child choose an animal and make their bodies into a “statue” of that animal. Have each child show their statue to the group and let the other children guess what animal statue they are.
Provide a writing prompt about creating sculptures and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Having children work collaboratively helps to promote social development, building skills in communication and problem solving. To work cooperatively, children must learn to listen to each other and to exchange ideas. Offer frequent opportunities for partner work.

section-block.rac_body-text: Give children crayons and paper. Remind children of the features of rectangles; then challenge them to draw one. Encourage them to draw as accurately as possible. Discuss why it takes practice and patience to draw a rectangle accurately, just like it took Joey practice and patience to become a master of origami. Congratulate children for trying their best!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read More-igami one last time this week.
Who remembers if this book tells us a story or teaches us information?
At first, Joey was not able to create perfect origami. He had to work to become an origami master. When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can you do to become a master of something?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the Big Book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to respond to the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is Mrs. Takimoto an origami master? Why do you think so?
Let’s pretend to be masters of origami by folding invisible paper! Show me how quickly you can fold. What shape are you making?
Joey will need patience to become an origami master. When have you needed patience to do something well? (MB)
Let’s practice our patience. Let’s sit quietly for five seconds before we move to the next page.
Is all this folding helping Joey become an origami master? What do you think?
Why does everyone lose patience with Joey when he practices? What does it look like when you lose your patience?
Joey’s practicing made him a master! Let’s pretend to celebrate with Joey.
The girl is SO surprised. Show me your best surprised face!
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What can you do to become a master of something?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can learn from someone who is already a master.
I can have patience as I learn to get better and better.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about mastering a task and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you need to become a master?
What would you like to become a master of?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Overcoming obstacles and working toward a goal is hard for grownups, let alone young children. Help children learn perseverance by breaking down tasks into steps, by standing back rather than taking over, and by praising their hard work and problem solving rather than their innate talent or intelligence.
